Comment: They voted for Trump because our system is flawed and they had legitimate complaints. Yes, they fell for soundbites and propaganda but my question is, what changes are the Democrats willing to make to win back our democracy and return fairness of opportunity? We can‚Äôt only blame Trump or those that voted for this mad house. We need real change that removes money and influence from our political system. We need  responsive government that isn‚Äôt just about social issues that spur emotional responses while they steal from us. We are burning our house down but tribal mud slinging won‚Äôt solve why we are here. Can we get together and figure out how to rebuild a better house that truly makes for a better America? One where taxes are paid equally. Where people can once again work three jobs and pull themselves out of poverty and truly live the American Dream instead of barely making rent? We need to create a more perfect union that creates fairness of opportunity and lifts all our citizens willing to fight for it! If we do get our country back, let‚Äôs not create another opportunity for Oligarchs and political elites to take over again by making both parties culpable for their part in getting us here.

Comment: More like self-inflicted‚Ä¶.the thing is he had personally already experienced tarriff during Trump's first term.  [I am one of the 500,000 soybean farmers in America](https://www.thefp.com/p/im-a-soybean-farmer-who-voted-for) who feels the pain. I rely on my own farm for 100 percent of the income for my family and the families of our three full-time workers. We have 1,500 acres of soybeans on my farm. At **$600 an acre, our production costs are $900,000.** But in the current climate, an acre brings in **only $500 of revenue, which means we‚Äôre yielding $750,000‚Äîa $150,000 loss.**  Caleb Ragland, 38, from Magnolia, Kentucky, who comes from a long line of farmers stretching back 200 years, is one of them‚Äî**having voted for Trump in 2016, 2020, and 2024.** Still, as the president of the American Soybean Association‚Äîrepresenting 500,000 soybean farmers across the country‚Äî**he is deeply concerned about how tariffs will impact him and his colleagues.**  **[The last trade war has caused lasting damage](https://www.cnbc.com/2025/03/11/how-trumps-trade-policy-is-putting-pressure-on-us-farmers.html).** To this day, the U.S. **has yet to fully recover its loss in market share of soybean exports to China**, the world‚Äôs number one buyer of the commodity, ‚Äú**Tariffs break trust,**‚Äù Ragland, who is also the president of the American Soybean Association, said. **‚ÄùIt‚Äôs a lot harder to find new customers than it is to retain ones that you already have.‚Äù**  [Many soybean farmers have been here before](https://www.thefp.com/p/im-a-soybean-farmer-who-voted-for?hide_intro_popup=true). After Trump imposed tariffs back in 2018 during his first term, **U.S. agriculture lost $26 billion‚Äînearly $20 billion in soybeans alone.** But Trump also emerged from that first trade war with a deal that many farmers celebrated. In fact, many **crop farmers in the American heartland helped reelect him in overwhelming numbers.**  Trump already weighing multi-billion-dollar tariff bailout for US farmers](https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/us-politics/trump-bailout-farmers-tariffs-b2726416.html) The last time Trump was in office, **his administration spent $23 billion in subsidy payments to farmers to protect them from his trade war then with China**, which purchased far fewer American agricultural products. Such payments, as they did then, would now **shield a vital voting base for Republicans.**
